'''Sustainable Development Goal 16''' (Goal 16, SDG16 or SDG 16) - peace, justice and strong institutions - is one of the 17 [[Sustainable Development Goals]] established by the [[United Nations]] in 2015. It "promote peaceful and inclusive societies for [[sustainable development]], provide access to justice for all and build effective, accountable and inclusive institutions at all levels".<ref>United Nations official website on SDGs: https://sustainabledevelopment.un.org/sdg16</ref> The Goal has 12 targets to be achieved by 2030. Progress towards targets will be measured by 23 indicators. [[File:Sustainable Development Goal 16.png|thumb|SDG 16: Peace, justice and strong institutions]]
== Background ==
=== The Sustainable Development Goals === {{See also|Sustainable Development Goals}} The Sustainable Development Goals are a collection of 17 global goals set by the [[United Nations]]. The broad goals are interrelated though each has its own targets to achieve. The total number of targets is 169. The SDGs cover a broad range of social and economic development issues. These include [[poverty]], [[hunger]], [[health]], [[education]], [[climate change]], [[gender equality]], [[Water supply|water,]] [[sanitation]], [[energy]], [[urbanization]], [[Environmental protection|environment]] and [[social justice]].<ref>https://sustainabledevelopment.un.org/content/documents/4538pressowg13.pdf</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.un.org/ga/search/view_doc.asp?symbol=A/RES/70/1&Lang=E|title=United Nations Official Document|website=www.un.org}}</ref>
The SDGs replace the [[Millennium Development Goals]] (MDGs), which started a global effort in 2002 to end poverty, achieve universal [[education]], [[Women's empowerment|empower women]], reduce [[child mortality]], improve [[maternal health]], combat diseases such as [[HIV]], ensure environment sustainability, and develop a global partnership for development.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.un.org/millenniumgoals/bkgd.shtml|title=United Nations Millennium Development Goals|website=www.un.org}}</ref> The Outcome Document of the UN Summit on the 2030 Agenda, ‘Transforming our world: the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development’, includes an emphasis on the importance of achieving progress on peaceful and inclusive societies, access to justice and rule of law, and effective, accountable and inclusive institutions.<ref name=":0">{{cite web|url=https://sustainabledevelopment.un.org/post2015/transformingourworld|title=Transforming our world: the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development .:. Sustainable Development Knowledge Platform|website=sustainabledevelopment.un.org}}</ref>
An annual report is prepared by the [[Secretary-General of the United Nations]] evaluating the progress towards the Sustainable Development Goals.<ref>See the 2017 report: http://www.un.org/ga/search/view_doc.asp?symbol=E/2017/66&Lang=E</ref> SDG 16 is going to be reviewed at the High-Level Political Forum in 2019.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://sustainabledevelopment.un.org/hlpf|title=High-level Political Forum .:. Sustainable Development Knowledge Platform|website=sustainabledevelopment.un.org}}</ref> [[File:Sustainable Development Goals.jpg|thumb|The 17 Sustainable Development Goals]]
=== Major agreements and convention ===
* Third International Conference on Small Island Developing States (SIDS Conference) * [[United Nations Conference on Sustainable Development]], Rio+20 * Millennium Declaration & Summit * [[Monterrey Consensus|International Conference on Financing for Development]] * [[Earth Summit 2002|World Summit on Sustainable Development]] * [[Earth Summit|Earth Summit+5]] * Conference on Environment & Development<ref>{{cite web|url=https://sustainabledevelopment.un.org/index.php?menu=122|title=Major Agreements & Conventions .:. Sustainable Development Knowledge Platform|website=sustainabledevelopment.un.org}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://sustainabledevelopment.un.org/resourcelibrary|title=Resources .:. Sustainable Development Knowledge Platform|website=sustainabledevelopment.un.org}}</ref>
== Links with other SDGs == The Sustainable Development Goals are not taken as being completely independent one from the other, but rather as being closely linked. In this way, [[media development]] enhances freedom of speech, peace, but also contributes to [[sustainability]], poverty eradication and [[human rights]].<ref name="unesco.org">{{cite web|url=https://en.unesco.org/themes/fostering-freedom-expression|title=Fostering Freedom of Expression|website=UNESCO}}</ref> Fostering peace and inclusive societies can help reduce inequalities (SDG10) and help economies prosper (SDG8).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.undp.org/content/undp/en/home/sustainable-development-goals/background.html|title=Background of the Sustainable Development Goals|website=UNDP}}</ref> The 2012 outcome document of the United Nations Summit on the 2030 Agenda considers that sustainable development can not be achieved without building peaceful, just and inclusive societies and addressing issues of corruption, poor governance, insecurity and injustice.<ref name=":0" /> Some SDGs can be considered as cross-cutting as a whole. It is the case for [[gender equality]] and [[Africa]], which are considered a global priority for UNESCO and a "critical factor for the achievement of all internationally agreed development goals".<ref>http://www.unesco.org/new/en/africa/
http://www.unesco.org/new/en/unesco/themes/gender-equality/</ref>
== Achievements ==
=== UNDP === The [[United Nations Development Programme]] is the United Nations [[International development|global development]] network who is also concerned with SDG 16 as the Programme focuses on [[Democracy|democratic governance]] and peace building.<ref>See official website: http://www.undp.org/content/undp/en/home/democratic-governance-and-peacebuilding.html</ref> The UNDP also works on conflict prevention by supporting empowering women and youth, and supporting regulatory frameworks and mechanisms and by acting as mediators.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.undp.org/content/undp/en/home/democratic-governance-and-peacebuilding/conflict-prevention.html|title=Conflict prevention - UNDP|website=UNDP}}</ref> UNDP has provided electoral assistance in over 50 countries.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ec-undp-electoralassistance.org/|title=EC-UNDP Joint Task Force - Partnership on Electoral Assistance|website=www.ec-undp-electoralassistance.org}}</ref>
=== UNESCO === UNESCO’s work on freedom of expression and the [[Safety of Journalists|safety of journalists]] contributes to Goal 16. UNESCO’s approach to media development tries to be knowledge-driven and context-sensitive. The Organization also wants to take into account the new challenges and opportunities of the media environment.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://en.unesco.org/sdgs/ci|title=Sustainable Development Goals for Communication and Information|website=UNESCO}}</ref> UNESCO's communication and information sector<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unesco.org/new/en/communication-and-information/|title=Communication and Information - United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization|website=www.unesco.org}}</ref> is responsible for targets 16.3 (access to justice), 16.5 (anti-corruption and transparent and accountable institutions). It aims to: "foster intercultural dialogue, culture of peace and non-violence, and prevent [[violent extremism]] through global citizenship education; support free, independent and pluralistic media, ensure the safety of journalists; protect cultural and natural heritage, strengthen [[Multi-stakeholder governance|governance]] systems for culture and enhance fundamental freedoms."<ref name="unesco.org1">http://unesdoc.unesco.org/images/0024/002477/247785e.pdf</ref>
==== Preventing violent extremism ==== Preventing [[violent extremism]] is a way to promote, in official wording, a "culture of peace and non-violence" for UNESCO. The Organization aims to prevent violent extremism by using education as a tool to strengthen [[global citizenship]], by mobilizing youth, women and other stakeholders - such as [[policy]]-makers, researchers and media actors - to take actions, online and offline, to prevent and respond to violent extremism and [[radicalization]] on the Internet<ref>http://unesdoc.unesco.org/images/0026/002603/260382e.pdf</ref> and to promote cultural diversity to foster more fair, inclusive and peaceful societies, through the #Unite4Heritage campaign<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unite4heritage.org/|title=#Unite4Heritage – Celebrating & Safeguarding Cultural Heritage - u4h|website=www.unite4heritage.org}}</ref> and Educational Programmes on Heritage and Creativity.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://en.unesco.org/themes/protecting-our-heritage-and-fostering-creativity|title=Protecting Our Heritage and Fostering Creativity|website=UNESCO}}</ref><ref name="unesco.org1"/>
==== Freedom of expression ==== {{Main|Freedom of speech}} Freedom of speech is a principle that supports the [[freedom]] of an individual or a community to articulate their opinions and ideas without fear of retaliation, [[censorship]], or sanction.<ref name="Mill 1859 1-5">{{cite book |last=Mill |first=John Stuart |date=1859 |chapter-url=http://www.bartleby.com/130/1.html |chapter=Introductory |url=http://www.bartleby.com/130/ |title=On Liberty |edition=4th |location=London |publisher=Longman, Roberts & Green |publication-date=1869 |at=para. 5 |quote=Society can and does execute its own mandates ... it practises a social tyranny more formidable than many kinds of political oppression, since, though not usually upheld by such extreme penalties, it leaves fewer means of escape, penetrating much more deeply into the details of life, and enslaving the soul itself. Protection, therefore, against the tyranny of the magistrate is not enough...}}</ref><ref name="Mill 1859 2-19">{{cite book |last=Mill |first=John Stuart |date=1859 |chapter-url=http://www.bartleby.com/130/2.html |chapter=Of the Liberty of Thought and Discussion |url=http://www.bartleby.com/130/ |title=On Liberty |edition=4th |location=London |publisher=Longman, Roberts & Green |publication-date=1869 |at=para. 19 |quote=In respect to all persons but those whose pecuniary circumstances make them independent of the good will of other people, opinion, on this subject, is as efficacious as law; men might as well be imprisoned, as excluded from the means of earning their bread.}}</ref><ref name="Ten Cate 2010">{{cite journal |last=Ten Cate |first=Irene M. |date=2010 |url=http://digitalcommons.law.yale.edu/yjlh/vol22/iss1/2 |title=Speech, Truth, and Freedom: An Examination of John Stuart Mill's and Justice Oliver Wendell Holmes's Free Speech Defenses |journal= Yale Journal of Law & the Humanities |volume=22 |issue=1 |at=Article 2 |quote=[A] central argument for freedom of speech in On Liberty is that in order to maximize the benefits a society can gain ... it must permanently commit to restraining dominant groups from their natural inclination to demand conformity.}}</ref><ref name="Wragg 2015">{{cite journal |last=Wragg |first=Paul |date=2015 |url=http://ilj.oxfordjournals.org/content/44/1/1.full.pdf |url-access=subscription |title=Free Speech Rights at Work: Resolving the Differences between Practice and Liberal Principle |journal=Industrial Law Journal |publisher=Oxford University Press |volume=44 |issue=1 |page=11 |quote=Comparison may be made between Mill's ‘tyrannical majority’ and the employer who dismisses an employee for expression that it dislikes on moral grounds. The protection of employer action in these circumstances evokes Mill's concern about state tolerance of coercive means to ensure conformity with orthodox moral viewpoints and so nullify unorthodox ones.}}</ref> UNESCO, as the United Nations agency with the specific mandate to promote “the free flow of ideas by word and image”, supports a free, independent and [[Pluralism (political theory)|pluralistic]] media in print, broadcast and on the Internet.<ref name="unesco.org"/> The Organization has projects that help building [[community media]] that involves the community in which the media develops as an alternative medium to public, commercial and social media.<ref>About community media: https://en.unesco.org/themes/community-media-sustainability</ref> It also promotes [[Information and media literacy|media and information literacy]],<ref>On Media and Information Literacy: http://www.unesco.org/new/en/communication-and-information/media-development/media-literacy/mil-as-composite-concept/</ref> [[Journalism literacy|journalism education]],<ref>About journalism education: http://www.unesco.org/new/en/communication-and-information/media-development/journalism-education-and-training/</ref> and professional journalistic standards and code of ethics.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unesco.org/new/en/communication-and-information/freedom-of-expression/professional-journalistic-standards-and-code-of-ethics/|title=Professional Journalistic Standards and Code of Ethics - United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization|website=www.unesco.org}}</ref>
==== Freedom of information laws ==== UNESCO advocates for the creation of national legislation on [[freedom of information]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.un.org/ga/search/view_doc.asp?symbol=E/2017/66&Lang=E|title=United Nations Official Document|website=www.un.org}}</ref>
==== Safety of journalists ==== {{Main|Safety of Journalists}} Safety of journalists is the ability for [[journalist]]s and media professionals to get, produce and share information without facing physical or moral threats. UNESCO's Freedom of Expression Section<ref name="unesco.org"/> and [[International Programme for the Development of Communication]] (IPDC) develop projects to address issues of safety of journalism and impunity in the field. [[UNESCO]] also celebrates [[World Press Freedom Day]] every year on May 3 during which the Guillermo Cano Prize<ref>{{cite web|url=https://en.unesco.org/prizes/guillermo-cano|title=UNESCO/Guillermo Cano World Press Freedom Prize|website=UNESCO}}</ref> is attributed to honor the work of an individual or an organization defending or promoting freedom of expression.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://en.unesco.org/commemorations/worldpressfreedomday|title=World Press Freedom Day|website=UNESCO}}</ref>
===== IPDC's follow-up on SDG 16 ===== The [[International Programme for the Development of Communication]] is responsible for the follow-up of the SDG 16 through indicators 16.10.1 and 16.10.2.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://unstats.un.org/sdgs/metadata/|title=SDG Indicators — SDG Indicators|first=United Nations Statistics|last=Division|website=unstats.un.org}}</ref> Every two years, a report containing information from the Member States on the status of judicial inquiries on each of the killings condemned by UNESCO is submitted to the IPDC Council by UNESCO's Director-General.<ref>http://unesdoc.unesco.org/images/0024/002460/246014E.pdf
https://en.unesco.org/programme/ipdc/initiatives</ref> The journalists safety indicators are a tool developed by UNESCO which, according to UNESCO's website, aims on mapping the key features that can help assess safety of journalists, and help determine whether adequate follow-up is given to crimes committed against them.<ref>For international-level indicators see: http://unesdoc.unesco.org/images/0026/002608/260892E.pdf For national-level indicators see: http://unesdoc.unesco.org/images/0026/002608/260893E.pdf</ref> The IPDC Talks also allow the Programme to raise awareness on the importance of [[access to information]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://en.unesco.org/powering-sustainable-development-access-information/about-ipdctalks|title=About the IPDCtalks|website=UNESCO}}</ref> The IPDC is also the programme that monitors and reports on access to information laws around the world through the [[Secretary-General of the United Nations|United Nations Secretary-General]] global report on follow-up to SDGs.
=== Organizations ===
==== Transparency International ==== The anti-corruption non-governmental organization [[Transparency International]] monitors corruption in over a hundred countries and aims to "gives voice to the victims and witnesses of corruption" and "stop the abuse of power, bribery and secret deals". The Organization launched the [[Corruption Perceptions Index]] in 1995.<ref>See official website: https://www.transparency.org/</ref>
==== Reporters without borders (RSF) ==== [[Reporters Without Borders|Reporters without borders]] is a French "independent" non-governmental organization with consultative status at the United Nations. The NGO promotes freedom of information and safety of journalists. RSF Advocates worldwide for international and national legislation on freedom of information and protection of journalists.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://rsf.org/en#instit|title=RSF|website=Bienvenue sur le site de Reporter sans frontières - RSF}}</ref> It has put together the 2018 World Press Freedom Index as a basis to analyze the state of freedom of expression.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://rsf.org/en/rsf-index-2018-hatred-journalism-threatens-democracies|title=RSF Index 2018: Hatred of journalism threatens democracies|website=RSF}}</ref>
==== World Wide Web Foundation ==== The [[World Wide Web Foundation]] is an association that promotes digital equality, access to information, and the open web as a "public good and a basic right". It advocates for public policies in over a dozen countries.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://webfoundation.org/about/|title=About|website=World Wide Web Foundation}}</ref>
== Sources == {{Free-content attribution | title = UNESCO moving forward the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development | author = | publisher = UNESCO | page numbers = 22 | source = | documentURL = http://unesdoc.unesco.org/images/0024/002477/247785e.pdf | license statement URL = http://www.unesco.org/ulis/cgi-bin/ulis.pl?catno=247785&set=005AE713D4_0_208&gp=1&lin=1&ll=1 | license = CC BY SA 3.0 IGO }}

{{Short description|multiple controversies regarding transgender students at Township High School District 211}} {{Use American English|date=August 2018}} {{As of|since=y|2015|post=,}} [[Township High School District 211]] (D211), a public school district of the [[Chicago suburbs]], has been the epicenter of multiple controversies surrounding its policies toward transgender student locker room access. D211 was the first school district to be found in violation of civil rights law on the basis of transgender issues by the [[United States Department of Education]]'s [[Office for Civil Rights]] (OCR).<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ed.gov/news/press-releases/settlement-reached-palatine-ill-township-high-school-district-211-remedy-transgender-discrimination|title=Settlement Reached with Palatine, Ill., Township High School District 211 to Remedy Transgender Discrimination {{!}} U.S. Department of Education|website=www.ed.gov|language=en|access-date=2018-07-19}}</ref> A lawsuit involving D211's policies toward transgender students was the first legal challenge to the [[Obama Administration]]'s interpretation of [[Title IX]] as allowing [[transgender]] students to use the locker room and bathroom facilities corresponding to their gender identity.<ref name = "wapo sue">{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/education/ill-group-sues-obama-administration-over-transgender-students-bathroom-access/2016/05/04/5c57ad12-1206-11e6-93ae-50921721165d_story.html|title=Illinois group sues Obama administration over transgender students’ bathroom access|website=Washington Post|language=en|access-date=2018-07-21}}</ref>
==Student A== ===Background=== {{further|Title IX|Gender identity under Title IX}} On June 23, 1972, Richard Nixon signed the [[Education Amendments of 1972]] into law, regarding the federal government's policies toward institutions of higher education.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.presidency.ucsb.edu/ws/?pid=3473|title=Richard Nixon: Statement on Signing the Education Amendments of 1972.|website=www.presidency.ucsb.edu|access-date=2018-07-20}}</ref> Title IX of the act states: {{Quote|text=No person in the United States shall, on the basis of sex, be excluded from participation in, be denied the benefits of, or be subjected to discrimination under any education program or activity receiving Federal financial assistance...|sign=|source=20 U.S.C. §§ 1681}}
Congress gave the executive branch wide purview in enforcing Title IX.<ref>20 U.S.C. §§ 1682</ref> While Title IX explicitly prohibits sex discrimination in educational programs and activities (including school athletic programs) which receive federal funding, it did not enumerate specific ways in which this was to be implemented.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.archives.gov/education/lessons/civil-rights-act|title=The Civil Rights Act of 1964 and the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission|date=2016-08-15|work=National Archives|access-date=2018-07-20|language=en}}</ref><ref name = "title ix">20 U.S.C. §§ 1681-1688</ref> The Department of Education has therefore historically created sub-regulatory guidance to enforce Title IX.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www2.ed.gov/policy/rights/reg/ocr/edlite-34cfr106.html|title=34 C.F.R. Part 106|website=www2.ed.gov|language=en|access-date=2018-07-20}}</ref> These rules must be followed by all educational institutions receiving federal dollars, including 16,500 school districts and 7,000 colleges, universities, and other post-secondary schools.<ref name = "OCR about">{{Cite web|url=https://www2.ed.gov/about/offices/list/ocr/docs/tix_dis.html?exp=0|title=Title IX and Sex Discrimination|date=2015-10-15|website=www2.ed.gov|language=en|access-date=2018-07-20}}</ref>
The Office for Civil Rights, which is responsible for implementing Title IX within the Department, issued several "[[Dear colleague letter (United States)|Dear Colleague]]" letters under the Obama Administration detailing public policy regarding LGBT students. In 2010, OCR released one such letter stating that while Title IX did not prohibit LGBT-based discrimination, it did prohibit discrimination toward LGBT students based wholly or in-part on sex.<ref name = "OCR 2010">{{Cite web|url=https://www2.ed.gov/about/offices/list/ocr/letters/colleague-201010.pdf|title="Dear Colleague" letter from Assistant Secretary for Civil Rights, Russlynn Ali (PDF).|last=Ali|first=Russlyn|date=October 26, 2010|website=Department of Education, Office for Civil Rights|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-07-20}}</ref> A 2014 document from the OCR stated that Title IX covered gender identity and gender nonconformity based discrimination.<ref>U.S. Dept. of Education, Office for Civil Rights, [http://www2.ed.gov/about/offices/list/ocr/docs/qa-201404-title-ix.pdf Questions and Answers on Title IX and Sexual Violence], April 29, 2014</ref>
===OCR investigation=== In December 2013, a student from [[William Fremd High School]], a part of District 211, filed a complaint under Title IX with the Office for Civil Rights. The student, named only as "Student A," was born male but identified as female at an early age. From the filing of the complaint onward, she was represented by the [[ACLU]] of Illinois.<ref name = "daily herald 1601">{{Cite news|url=http://www.dailyherald.com/article/20160115/news/160119309/|title=Transgender student gains locker room access at Fremd High School|last=Peterson|first=Eric|work=Daily Herald|access-date=2018-07-20|language=en-US}}</ref><ref name = "OCR letter">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2015/11/02/us/document-letter-from-the-us-dept-of-education-to-daniel-cates.html|title=Letter From the Office for Civil Rights|access-date=2018-07-20|language=en}}</ref> Student A's complaint alleged that the district had discriminated against her because she was denied use of the girls' locker room and was required to dress in a separate, private bathroom. D211 said that in making their decision to deny access, they weighed Student A's rights with the right of other students to privacy. D211 determined that they could not allow Student A access because it would result in students of opposite biological sex viewing each other's bodies. OCR found the concerns to be "unavailing." OCR told the district in July 2015 that it had violated Title IX because it discriminated against Student A on the basis of sex. Neither OCR nor Student A alleged that there was a hostile environment or that the district's discrimination went beyond locker room access. In October 2015, the district installed privacy curtains in the girls' locker room and stated that it would not allow Student A to change in the locker room unless she was required to use the privacy curtains. Student A said she would use the curtains if available. OCR disagreed with the district's stated policy of requiring Student A to change behind the curtains because "those female students wishing to protect their own private bodies from exposure... could change behind a privacy curtain."<ref name = "OCR letter"/><ref name = "pre herald">{{Cite news|url=http://www.dailyherald.com/article/20151012/news/151019750/|title=Dist. 211 setting up private changing room for transgender student|last=Silverberg|first=Melissa|work=Daily Herald|access-date=2018-07-20|language=en-US}}</ref><ref name = "nyt mid">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/11/03/us/illinois-district-violated-transgender-students-rights-us-says.html|title=Illinois District Violated Transgender Student’s Rights, U.S. Says|access-date=2018-07-20|language=en}}</ref> Allowing Student A access to the girls' locker room with the requirement that she change in private was not an acceptable solution to OCR.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnn.com/2015/11/03/us/illinois-school-district-transgender-ruling/index.html|title=Illinois district must give full locker room access to transgender student - CNN|last=CNN|first=Ed Payne and John Newsome,|work=CNN|access-date=2018-07-21}}</ref>
OCR and D211 engaged in negotiations nine times to resolve the Title IX violation. On October 12, 2015, the district stated that it would not resolve the issue voluntarily following a collective decision by the school board and district administration. On November 2, 2015, OCR sent a letter to D211 superintendent Dr. Daniel Cates to inform him that if an agreement was not reached in 30 days, it would enforce Title IX.<ref name = "OCR letter"/><ref name = "pre herald"/> Enforcement could have jeopardized the yearly $6 million in federal funding which D211 received. At the time, the district's budget was $240 million.<ref name = "pre herald"/> Superintendent Cates viewed the decision as an overreach.<ref name = "nyt mid"/>
===D211 response=== On December 2–3,{{efn|name="midnight"|The meeting began at 7:30 PM December 2 and concluded at 12:37 AM the next day.}} 2015, the last days before OCR would enforce Title IX, D211 held a school board meeting to determine what action should be taken. In the preceding month, the district had negotiated with OCR and reached a resolution agreement approved by OCR but requiring a vote by the school board. The agreement was summarized as follows:<ref name = "tribune meeting">{{Cite news|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/suburbs/schaumburg-hoffman-estates/news/ct-transgender-student-district-211-vote-met-20151202-story.html#|title=District 211 votes to give transgender student access to girls' locker room|last=Eldeib|first=Duaa|work=chicagotribune.com|access-date=2018-07-20|language=en-US}}</ref><ref name = "board minutes">{{Cite web|url=https://adc.d211.org/cms/lib/IL49000007/Centricity/Domain/47/December-2-Board-Minutes.pdf|title=December-2-Board-Minutes.pdf|last=|first=|date=December 2, 2015|website=D211|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-07-20}}</ref> {{quote| * Based on the representation of the individual student who filed the OCR complaint that the student will change in private changing stations, the district agrees to provide the student with access to locker room facilities designated for the student's identified gender; * Any student will have access to privacy accommodations in the locker room through a variety of individual options; * This agreement pertains solely to this individual student and does not require a district-wide policy; * The agreement makes no reference to the District violating any regulation or law and reiterates that the District categorically refutes the notion of any violation of law or form of discrimination. |sign=Mucia Burke, President of the D211 School Board}}
The board meeting included a two-hour period for public comment. Parents and students addressed the board with their views regarding Student A's use of the locker room. A majority of comments were against the settlement.<ref name = "tribune meeting"/>
After a three-hour closed-door meeting, the school board voted 5–2 to accept the agreement with OCR.<ref name = "tribune meeting"/> Mike Scharringhausen, Anna Klimkowicz, Robert LeFevre, Will Hinshaw, and Mucia Burke voted for the resolution. Lauanna Recker and Peter Dombrowski voted against.<ref name = "board minutes"/>
====Disagreement over the agreement==== The agreement between D211 and OCR included language which stated that the district would allow Student A girls' locker room access "based on Student A’s representation that she will change in private changing stations."<ref name = "agreement">{{Cite web|url=https://www2.ed.gov/documents/press-releases/township-high-211-agreement.pdf|title=Agreement: Township High School District 211, Palatine, Illinois: OCR Case #05-14-1055 -- December 3, 2015|last=|first=|date=December 3, 2015|website=Department of Education, Office for Civil Rights|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-07-20}}</ref> The agreement did not state specifically that Student A would be required to change in a privacy stall.<ref name = "tribune 7">{{Cite news|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/local/breaking/ct-transgender-student-district-211-settlement-update-met-20151207-story.html|title=District 211 keeps deal on transgender student after heated debate|last=Eldeib|first=Duaa|work=chicagotribune.com|access-date=2018-07-21|language=en-US}}</ref> The district would also have to take a number of other measures as part of the resolution, including providing a "reasonable alternative" to any student who requested additional privacy.<ref name = "tribune post post">{{Cite news|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/suburbs/schaumburg-hoffman-estates/ct-transgender-student-settlement-district-211-met-20151203-story.html|title=Transgender student locker room case settled, but controversy remains|last=Eldeib|first=Duaa|work=chicagotribune.com|access-date=2018-07-21|language=en-US}}</ref> District officials had said that the terms of the agreement with OCR only applied to Student A. On December 3, after the board voted to accept the resolution, [[Catherine E. Lhamon|Catherine Lhamon]] of OCR said that it was "facially inconsistent with the terms of the agreement" for the district to adopt this view, adding that OCR would continue to enforce Title IX in any case where the district refused locker room access. In addition, Lhamon said that the agreement allowed Student A unrestricted access to the locker room.<ref name = "herald post post">{{Cite news|url=http://www.dailyherald.com/article/20151207/news/151209129/|title=Dist. 211 reaffirms transgender locker room deal|last=Peterson|first=Eric|work=Daily Herald|access-date=2018-07-21|language=en-US}}</ref><ref name = "tribune post post"/> On December 4, Superintendent Cates released a statement in response to Lhamon which reiterated the district's view that the agreement only applied to Student A. In that statement, Cates also said that if Student A's actions did not match her representation that she would change in private, the district would revoke her girls' locker room access. A statement later released by the ACLU spokesman Ed Yohnka agreed with OCR's view that the agreement did not require Student A to change in private.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.dailyherald.com/article/20151204/news/151209388/|title=District 211 threatens to abandon transgender agreement|last=Peterson|first=Eric|work=Daily Herald|access-date=2018-07-21|language=en-US}}</ref> Yohnka also said that it would seem unreasonable for OCR not to defend any other transgender student who should request locker room access consistent with gender identity. On December 7, the district received a letter from Lhamon which stated that the agreement provisions specific to locker room access did not apply district-wide. Furthermore, Lhamon said that D211 agreeing to allow Student A access to the girl's locker room "is based on the student's representation that she will change in private changing stations."<ref name = "herald post post"/><ref name = "tribune 7"/>—language very similar to the terminology already at issue in the agreement.<ref name = "agreement"/> The ''Chicago Tribune'' noted that both OCR and D211 seemed to agree that the provisions regarding locker room access applied in one case, while the other provisions of the resolution applied district-wide.<ref name = "tribune 7"/>
D211 held a school board meeting on December 7, four days after they had accepted the resolution, to reassess the district's standing relative to the agreement. As before, the district had a period for public comment, which was significantly more supportive of Student A's case than the previous one. After a lengthy closed-door meeting, the school board announced that it would not overturn the agreement.<ref name = "tribune 7"/><ref name = "7 meeting">{{Cite web|url=https://adc.d211.org/cms/lib/IL49000007/Centricity/Domain/47/Approval-of-Minutes-Special-Meeting-of-December-7-2015.pdf|title=Approval of Minutes -- Special Meeting of December 7 2015|last=|first=|date=December 7, 2015|website=D211|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-07-21}}</ref>
===Policy changes=== On May 13, 2016, the Department of Education and Department of Justice issued a "Dear Colleague" letter which updated the federal government's official view on Title IX. In general, the letter stated that discrimination based on transgender status or gender identity is sex discrimination, and is therefore prohibited under Title IX.{{efn|name="overturned"|As mentioned above, after the Obama administration, OCR under President Trump issued another "Dear Colleague" letter in 2017 which overturned these provisions. See [[#Background 2|§§ Background]] under [[#Nova Maday|§ Nova Maday]].}} The letter spoke specifically on transgender student use of bathrooms and locker rooms, citing Student A's case resolution:<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www2.ed.gov/about/offices/list/ocr/letters/colleague-201605-title-ix-transgender.pdf|title=Archived: Dear Colleague Letter on Transgender Students|last=|first=|date=May 13, 2016|website=Department of Education, Office for Civil Rights|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-07-21}}</ref> {{quote|A school may not require transgender students to use facilities inconsistent with their gender identity or to use individual-user facilities when other students are not required to do so. A school may, however, make individual-user options available to all students who voluntarily seek additional privacy.}}
===Lawsuit=== On May 4, 2016, a group of D211 students and parents sued the district, Department of Education, and [[United States Department of Justice|Department of Justice]] in federal court, alleging that allowing Student A access to the girls' locker room was a violation of their civil rights.<ref name = "wapo sue"/><ref name = "herald first sue">{{Cite news|url=http://www.dailyherald.com/article/20160504/news/160509515/|title=District 211 sued over transgender student's locker room access|last=Peterson|first=Eric|work=Daily Herald|access-date=2018-07-21|language=en-US}}</ref> The group, Parents for Privacy (sometimes called D211 Parents for Privacy, Students and Parents for Privacy, or simply PFP), said that the federal government violated the students' privacy rights as well as the parents' constitutional rights to "instill moral standards and values in their children." The Thomas More Society and the Alliance Defending Freedom supported PFP in the suit.<ref name = "wapo sue"/>
On May 26, 2016, Student A, two younger transgender students (called Students B and C), and the Illinois Safe Schools Alliance filed a [[Intervention (law)|motion to intervene]] in the PFP lawsuit. Student B and Student C both attended feeder schools to D211.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.dailyherald.com/article/20160526/news/160529098/|title=Student at center of District 211 transgender debate hopes to join lawsuit|last=Hegarty|first=Erin|work=Daily Herald|access-date=2018-07-21|language=en-US}}</ref> All three students were represented by the ACLU. In June, [[Judge Jorge Alonso]] granted the motion. The district did not oppose.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.dailyherald.com/article/20160615/news/160619315/|title=Judge: ACLU can intervene in District 211 transgender lawsuit|last=Peterson|first=Eric|work=Daily Herald|access-date=2018-07-21|language=en-US}}</ref>
In August 2016, PFP sought an [[injunction]] which would temporarily prevent transgender students from any access to the school locker rooms which matched their gender identity. In October 2016, Magistrate Judge Jeffrey Gilbert recommended that the injunction be denied because high school students "do not have a constitutional right not to share restrooms or locker rooms with transgender students whose sex assigned at birth is different than theirs."<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/local/breaking/ct-transgender-student-locker-room-palatine-20161018-story.html|title=Judge sides against parents who want to ban transgender student from locker room in District 211|last=Eldeib|first=Duaa|work=chicagotribune.com|access-date=2018-07-21|language=en-US}}</ref>
In May 2017, Student A graduated from William Fremd High School. The lawsuit was not dropped because the case was considered "[[capable of repetition, yet evading review]]."<ref name = "graduation no">{{Cite news|url=http://www.dailyherald.com/news/20170522/transgender-studentx2019s-graduation-wonx2019t-end-district-211-lawsuit|title=Transgender student's graduation won't end District 211 lawsuit|last=Peterson|first=Eric|work=Daily Herald|access-date=2018-07-22|language=en-US}}</ref> In July, PFP dropped the Department of Education and Department of Justice as defendants because under the Trump Administration they had rescinded the Obama-era policies which interpreted Title IX as requiring schools to provide locker room access based on gender identity.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.dailyherald.com/news/20170710/federal-defendants-dropped-from-district-211-transgender-lawsuit|title=Federal defendants dropped from District 211 transgender lawsuit|last=Peterson|first=Eric|work=Daily Herald|access-date=2018-07-22|language=en-US}}</ref>
In December 2017, Judge Alonso denied PFP the injunction they had filed for in August 2016, agreeing with the preliminary decision made by Magistrate Judge Gilbert. Alonso said that there was "no indication that anything has negatively impacted" the education of the PFP students. At the time, PFP's attorneys said they were reviewing options to appeal.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/suburbs/ct-met-palatine-school-transgender-ruling-20180102-story.html|title=Judge refuses to order Palatine school district to suspend transgender policy|last=services|first=Chicago Tribune, wire|work=chicagotribune.com|access-date=2018-07-22|language=en-US}}</ref>
===Election=== {| class="wikitable sortable floatright" |+2017 D211 school board race{{efn|name="tablenote"|Each voter was instructed to vote for three candidates; the three candidates with the most votes were awarded board seats (highlighted in blue).}}<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cookcountyclerk.com/elections/results/Documents/SummaryReport40417.pdf|title=Summary Report (2 Column)|last=|first=|date=April 4, 2017|website=Cook County Clerk|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170712001314/https://www.cookcountyclerk.com/elections/results/Documents/SummaryReport40417.pdf|archive-date=July 12, 2017|dead-url=|access-date=2018-07-22}}</ref> ! Candidate ! Votes (#) ! Votes (%) |- |data-sort-value="Klimkowicz" style="background: SkyBlue;"|Anna Klimkowicz||style="text-align: right;background: SkyBlue;"|10,093||style="text-align: right;background: SkyBlue;"|20.16% |- |data-sort-value="LeFevre" style="background: SkyBlue;"|Robert LeFevre||style="text-align: right;background: SkyBlue;"|8,843||style="text-align: right;background: SkyBlue;"|17.66% |- |data-sort-value="Yung" style="background: SkyBlue;"|Edward Yung||style="text-align: right;background: SkyBlue;"|8,267||style="text-align: right;background: SkyBlue;"|16.51% |- |data-sort-value="David"|Katherine David||style="text-align: right;"|8,045||style="text-align: right;"|16.07% |- |data-sort-value="Bonatz"|Ralph Bonatz||style="text-align: right;"|7,412||style="text-align: right;"|14.80% |- |data-sort-value="Forrest"|Jean Forrest||style="text-align: right;"|7,340||style="text-align: right;"|14.66% |- |data-sort-value="Write-in"|Write-in||style="text-align: right;"|73||style="text-align: right;"|0.15% |- !style="text-align: left;"|Total !style="text-align: right;"|50,073 !style="text-align: right;"|100.00% |} On April 4, 2017, D211 held an election for three<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/04/02/us/transgender-students-township-illinois.html|title=A Transgender Student Won Her Battle. Now It’s War.|access-date=2018-07-22|language=en}}</ref> of the seven board seats.<ref name = "board minutes"/> The seats of Robert LeFevre, Anna Klimkowicz, and Mike Scharringhausen were up for election; LeFevre and Klimkowicz ran for reelection.<ref name = "herald election">{{Cite news|url=http://www.dailyherald.com/article/20161221/news/161229676/|title=District 211, 15 school board races among most contentious|last=Peterson|first=Eric|work=Daily Herald|access-date=2018-07-22|language=en-US}}</ref> All three seats were occupied by board members who voted to accept the agreement with OCR.<ref name = "board minutes"/> The other candidates for the three open board seats were Katherine David, Ralph Bonatz, Jean Forrest, and former board member Edward Yung.<ref name = "herald election"/> David, Bonatz, and Forrest ran as a slate who publicly opposed the board's agreement with OCR.<ref name = "wapo election">{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/in-suburban-chicago-transgender-students-quest-to-use-locker-room-defines-school-board-race/2017/04/03/82a4e6de-156a-11e7-833c-503e1f6394c9_story.html|title=Transgender student’s quest to use girls’ locker room defines school board race in Chicago suburb|last=|website=Washington Post|language=en|access-date=2018-07-22}}</ref> The three had pledged to end gender identity-based locker room access to transgender students as well as bathroom access,<ref name = "tribune election">{{Cite news|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/local/breaking/ct-transgender-student-access-school-board-election-met-20170403-story.html|title=Transgender controversy dominates high school board election|last=McCoppin|first=Kate Thayer, Robert|work=chicagotribune.com|access-date=2018-07-22|language=en-US}}</ref> which the district had allowed previously without pressure from OCR.<ref name = "agreement"/> LeFevre, Klimkowicz, and Yung ran independently of each other, but generally supported the agreement with OCR.<ref name = "wapo election"/><ref name = "tribune election"/>
Klimkowicz, LeFevre, and Yung won the three open board seats.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.dailyherald.com/article/20170404/news/170409585/|title=Incumbents, former board member win in District 211|last=Peterson|first=Eric|work=Daily Herald|access-date=2018-07-22|language=en-US}}</ref>
==Nova Maday== ===Background=== On February 22, 2017, OCR and the Department of Justice released another "Dear Colleague" letter on transgender students. This letter withdrew the 2016 letter released under President Obama which had generally stated that discrimination based on gender identity and transgender status were prohibited under Title IX. Under these guidelines, OCR would not require schools to give gender identity-based bathroom and locker room access to transgender students.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www2.ed.gov/about/offices/list/ocr/letters/colleague-201702-title-ix.pdf|title=Dear Colleague Letter on Transgender Students|last=|first=|date=February 22, 2017|website=Department of Education, Office for Civil Rights|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-07-22}}</ref>
Title IX does not expressly prohibit discrimination based on gender identity, but it does expressly prohibit discrimination based on sex in schools receiving federal funding. The Obama Administration was able to extend Title IX protection to gender identity because Congress gave the executive branch some power in interpreting and implementing Title IX. For the same reason, the Trump Administration was able to implement Title IX in a way which does not cover gender identity.<ref name = "title ix"/> Unlike Title IX, the State of Illinois explicitly prohibits discrimination based on both sex and gender identity in public high schools. The State also allows certain private facilities such as bathrooms and locker rooms to be exempted from restrictions on sex discrimination.<ref>"Sec. 5-102. Civil Rights Violations: Public Accommodations. It is a civil rights violation for any person on the basis of unlawful discrimination to: (A) Enjoyment of Facilities, Goods, and Services. Deny or refuse to another the full and equal enjoyment of the facilities, goods, and services of any public place of accommodation"; the act includes "non-sectarian secondary schools" as public places of accommodation and includes sexual orientation (including gender identity) based discrimination in its definition of unlawful discrimination. {{Cite web|url=http://www.ilga.gov/legislation/ilcs/ilcs5.asp?ActID=2266|title=Illinois Human Rights Act|website=www.ilga.gov|language=en|access-date=2018-07-22}}</ref>
In May 2017, Student A graduated from D211, terminating the agreement with OCR. Although the agreement's provisions specific to locker room access applied only to Student A, the district allowed other transgender students gender identity-based locker room access under similar terms.<ref name = "graduation no"/>
===Case=== On November 30, 2017, Nova Maday, a transgender senior at [[Palatine High School]], filed a state lawsuit against D211 with the help of the ACLU and a Chicago law firm. She alleged that the district had discriminated against her by denying her full use of the girls' locker room. Maday said that the district had initially refused her any access to the girls' locker room and then granted her limited access on the pretense that she would change in private. According to the lawsuit, this requirement was not implemented for other students and negatively impacted Maday's mental health and grade in physical education. She contended that this was a violation of the Illinois Human Rights Act and sought gender identity-based locker room access for all students as well as damages for emotional distress and loss. Superintendent Cates said that Maday's lawsuit misrepresented the accommodations the district had made for her.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/suburbs/ct-met-palatine-transgender-student-sues-20171130-story.html|title=Lawsuit: 2nd transgender student fights for locker room access at Palatine district|last=Lourgos|first=Angie Leventis|work=chicagotribune.com|access-date=2018-07-22|language=en-US}}</ref>
In January 2018, PFP and the Thomas More Society successfully intervened in Maday's lawsuits as defendants.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.dailyherald.com/news/20180118/judge-citizens-group-can-intervene-in-district-211-transgender-suit|title=Judge: Citizens group can intervene in District 211 transgender suit|last=Peterson|first=Eric|work=Daily Herald|access-date=2018-07-22|language=en-US}}</ref>
Maday sought an injunction which would temporarily remove the requirement that she change in private in the girls' locker room.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://chicago.suntimes.com/education/palatine-transgender-student-locker-room-access-private-changing-area/|title=Transgender student in Palatine denied unrestricted locker room access|work=Chicago Sun-Times|access-date=2018-07-22|language=en}}</ref> On January 25, 2018, Judge Thomas Allen denied her request because the Illinois Human Rights Act required only "access" to school facilities, instead of "full and equal access" which was removed from the final draft of the bill.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/suburbs/ct-met-transgender-student-lawsuit-palatine-20180125-story.html|title=Transgender student who sued Palatine school district over locker room access loses round in court|last=Schmadeke|first=Steve|work=chicagotribune.com|access-date=2018-07-22|language=en-US}}</ref>
Maday appealed the ruling of Judge Allen. Although Maday graduated in May 2018, the appellate court took her case under consideration because it was likely to repeat.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/local/breaking/ct-met-transgender-palatine-high-lawsuit-20180625-story.html|title=Appellate court considers locker room case from former Palatine High transgender student|last=Cherney|first=Elyssa|work=chicagotribune.com|access-date=2018-07-22|language=en-US}}</ref>

{{One source|date=October 2010}} {{Politics of Turkey}} The '''Constitution of 1961''', officially titled the '''Constitution of the Republic of Turkey''' ({{lang-tr|Türkiye Cumhuriyeti Anayasası}}), was the [[constitution|fundamental law]] of [[Turkey]] from 1961 to 1982. It was introduced following the [[1960 Turkish coup d'état|1960 ''coup d'état'']], replacing the earlier [[Turkish Constitution of 1924|Constitution of 1924]]. It was approved in a referendum held on 9 July 1961,<ref name="Palabiyik2008">{{cite book |last=Palabiyik |first=Hamit |title=Turkish public administration: from tradition to the modern age |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DWceNjwTggUC&pg=PA46 |accessdate=8 July 2011 |year=2008 |publisher=USAK Books |isbn=978-605-4030-01-9 |page=46}}</ref> with 61.7% of the nation voting in favor. It remained in force until the [[1980 Turkish coup d'état|1980 ''coup d'état'']], following which it was replaced by a new document, the [[Constitution of Turkey|Constitution of 1982]], which remains in force today.
==General principles== ===I. Form of the state=== Article 1 - The Turkish State is a republic.
===II. Characteristics of the Republic=== Article 2 - The Turkish Republic is a nationalistic, democratic, secular and social state, governed by the rule of law, based on human rights and fundamental tenets set forth in the preamble.
===III. Indivisibility of the State, its official language and its seat of government=== Article 3 - The Turkish State is an indivisible whole comprising its territory and people. Its official language is Turkish. Its capital is the city of Ankara.
===IV. Sovereignty=== Article 4 - Sovereignty is vested in the nation without reservation and condition. The nation shall exercise its sovereignty through the authorized agencies as prescribed by the principles laid forth in the Constitution. The right to exercise such sovereignty shall not be delegated to any one person, group or class. No person or agency shall exercise any state authority, which does not derive its origin from the Constitution.
===V. Legislative Power=== Article 5 - Legislative power is vested in the Grand National Assembly. This power shall not be delegated.
===VI. Executive Function=== Article 6 - The executive function shall be carried out by the President of the Republic and the Council of Ministers within the framework of law.
===VII. Judicial Power=== Article 7 - Judicial power shall be exercised by independent courts on behalf of the Turkish nation.
===VIII. Supremacy and the binding force of the Constitution=== Article 8 - Laws shall not be in conflict with the Constitution. The provisions of the Constitution shall be the fundamental legal principles binding the legislative, executive and judicial organs, administrative authorities and individuals.
===IX. Irrevocability of the form of the State=== Article 9 - The provision of the Constitution establishing the form of the state as a republic shall not be amended nor shall any motion therefore be made.
==Difference between 1924 and 1961 constitutions== {{further|Constitutional History of Turkey}} Unlike the former constitution, the new constitution was based on human rights; with Article 11, the individual's freedom was secured at all times. The phrase ''social state'' was included in this Constitution for the first time. The new constitution also introduced the Senate, to form a [[bicameral]] system with the National Assembly.
The [[Grand National Assembly]] was formed of the National Assembly and Senate of the Republic. The National Assembly and the majority of senators were elected by the nation, but 15 senators were chosen by the President among former presidents and members of the [[Committee of National Unity]], which had organised the ''coup d'état''
==References== *{{cite web | url = http://www.anayasa.gen.tr/1961constitution-text.pdf | title = 1961 Constitution | accessdate = 2007-04-14 }} {{en icon}} {{reflist}}

{{Monarchism |expanded=Varieties}} {{Forms of government}} {{More citations needed|date=March 2010}}
A '''Universal Monarchy''' is a concept and a political situation where one monarchy is deemed to have either sole rule over everywhere (or at least the predominant part of a [[geopolitical]] area or areas) or to have a special supremacy over all other states (or at least all the states in a geopolitical area or areas).
==Concept==
Universal Monarchy is differentiated from ordinary [[monarchy]] in that a Universal Monarchy is beholden to no other state and asserts a degree of total sovereignty over an area, or predominance over other states.
The concept has arisen in [[Europe]] and [[Asia]]. The concept is linked to that of [[Empire]], but implies more than simply possessing ''[[imperium]]''.
The Latin phrase ''Dominus Mundi'', Lord of the World, encapsulates the concept. Though in practice no Universal Monarchy ever held rule over the whole world, it may have appeared to many people, particularly pre-modern, that it did.
Critical of the concept in Europe in the Middle Ages were philosophers such as [[Nicole Oresme]]<ref>Mastnak, Tomaž ''Crusading peace: Christendom, the Muslim world, and Western political order'' University of California Press (2002) p329</ref> and [[Erasmus]];<ref>Persson, Hans-Åke & Stråth, Bo ''Reflections on Europe: defining a political order in time and space'' Peter Lang (2007) pp51-52</ref> whereas [[Dante]] and [[Guillaume Postel]]<ref>Kuntz, Marion Leathers ''Guillaume Postel, prophet of the restitution of all things: his life and thought'' Springer (1981) p171</ref> were more favourable. Later, [[Protestants]] would seek to reject the concept, identifying it with [[Catholic Church|Catholicism]].<ref>Simms, Brendan & Riotte, Torsten (Editors) ''The Hanoverian dimension in British History, 1714-1837'' Cambridge University Press (2007) pp168-169</ref>
==History==
===Europe=== In Europe the expression of a Universal Monarchy as actual total ''imperium'' can be seen in the [[Roman Empire]], and as the predominate ‘sole sovereign’ state during its [[Byzantine]] period, where the Emperor by virtue of being the head of [[Christendom]] claimed a sovereignty over all other kings even though in practice this could not be enforced. The Byzantine conception went through two phases, initially as expounded by [[Eusebius]] that just as there was one God so there could only be one Emperor,<ref>Nicol, D.M. ''Byzantine political thought'' in Burns, J. H. ''The Cambridge history of medieval political thought c. 350-c. 1450'' Cambridge University Press 1988 pp52-53</ref> which developed in the 10th century into the conception of the Emperor as the ''[[paterfamilias]]'' of a family of kings who were the other rulers in the world.<ref>Nicol, D.M. ''Byzantine political thought'' in Burns, J. H. ''The Cambridge history of medieval political thought c. 350-c. 1450'' Cambridge University Press 1988 p57</ref> Such concepts were a feature of the [[Ottoman Empire]] successor state, particularly when military rule was augmented by the [[Caliphate]].
The idea of a sole sovereign Emperor would re-emerge in the West with [[Charlemagne]] and the [[Holy Roman Empire]].<ref>Bryce, James ''The Holy Roman Empire'' p209</ref> The idea of the Holy Roman Empire possessing a special sovereignty as a Universal Monarchy was respected by the surrounding powers and subject states, even when that Empire had undergone severe fragmentation.<ref>Brissaud, Jean ''A History of French Public Law'' John Murray (1915) p77</ref> The symbolism of the [[A.E.I.O.U.]] phrase of [[Frederick III, Holy Roman Emperor|Frederick III]] can be seen as an expression of the idea of all states being subject to one monarchy.
[[Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor|Charles V]]’s empire, encompassing much of western Europe and the Americas “was the nearest the post-classical world would come to seeing a truly world-wide monarchy, and hence the closest approximation to universal imperium” since the Roman Empire.<ref>Armitage, David ''The Ideological Origins of the British Empire'' Cambridge University Press (2000) p32</ref> It was envisaged by its supporters as a world empire that could be religiously inclusive.<ref>Ocker, Christopher, Printy ,Michael & Starenko, Peter (Editors) ''Politics and Reformations: Communities, Politics, Nations, and Empires'' Brill Academic Publishers (2007), 495.</ref>
Subsequently, the idea of a Universal Monarchy based on predominance rather than actual total rule would become synonymous with France attempting to establish hegemony over western Europe, particularly under [[Louis XIV]],<ref>Simms, Brendan & Riotte, Torsten (Editors)''The Hanoverian dimension in British History, 1714-1837'' Cambridge University Press (2007) p168</ref> exemplified by the concept of Louis XIV as the 'Sun King' around which all the other monarchs became subordinate satellites. In 1755, during the reign of Louis XIV's successor [[Louis XV]], Duke [[Adrien Maurice de Noailles]], a member of the Council of State and formerly a key foreign policy advisor to the king, warned of a British challenge for "the first rank in Europe" through the domination of Atlantic commerce. Noailles wrote "However chimerical the project of universal monarchy might be, that of a universal influence by means of wealth would cease to be a chimera if a nation succeeded in making itself sole mistress of the trade of America."<ref>{{cite journal |last=Shovlin |first=John |date=2010 |title=Selling American Empire on the Eve of the Seven Years War: The French Propaganda Campaign of 1755-1756 |journal=Past and Present |volume=206 |issue=1 |pages=121–149 |doi=10.1093/pastj/gtp046 }}</ref>
Universal Monarchy would flourish at either end of Europe, in Britain and Russia. The Russian Universal Monarchy was [[Russian Orthodox Church|Orthodox]], [[Autocracy|autocratic]] and possessed a vast contiguous empire throughout Europe and Asia and can be seen to have similarities and differences with Byzantine rule.<ref>Gavrov, Sergey [http://ru.wikipedia.org/?oldid=48502217]''Modernization of the Empire. Social and Cultural Aspects of Modernization Processes in Russia'' URSS (2004) p50</ref> The British Universal Monarchy was “[[Protestant]], commercial, maritime and free”<ref>see Armitage, David ''The Ideological Origins of the British Empire'' Cambridge University Press (2000)</ref> and was not composed of contiguous territory. It had both similarities and difference with the [[Spanish Empire]]. Whereas [[Catholicism]] provided ideological unity for the Spanish Empire, British Protestant diversity would lead to “disunity rather than unity”.<ref>Armitage, David ''The Ideological Origins of the British Empire'' Cambridge University Press (2000) p66</ref> It was only later that [[federalism]] and economic control was seen as a means to provide unity where religious diversity could not, as with the idea of [[Imperial Federation]] as promoted by [[Joseph Chamberlain]].
[[Napoleon]] came close to creating something akin to a Universal Monarchy with his [[continental system]] and [[Napoleonic Code]], but he failed to conquer all of Europe. The last attempt to create a European Universal Monarchy was that attempted by [[Imperial Germany]] in [[World War I]]. If Germany had been victorious, the German Kaiser would have been suzerain over most of Europe.<ref>Fischer, Fritz. ''Germany's Aims in the First World War''. (1967)</ref><ref>Niall, Ferguson, ''Virtual History: Alternatives and Counterfactuals'' (1999).</ref>
===Asia=== {{Expand section|date=March 2010}} A parallel process occurred in Asia. Whereas in the West the title of Emperor had by the 19th century largely been stripped of religious connotations and had come to be seen purely in political terms, the title in eastern Asia is almost entirely a religious one, commonly stated as "the [[son of heaven]]". Here the title denotes a higher, "heavenly" rule ("celestial empire"), in contrast to kings who rule between heaven and earth, and by extension today to presidents who are mere base earthly rulers. Imperial China was a Universal Monarchy where all other monarchs were regarded as tributary. The concept was taken up by the Mongols,<ref>Marshall, Robert''Storm from the East: from Genghis Khan to Khubilai Khan'' University of California Press (1993)p156</ref><ref>Sicker, Martin ''The Islamic world in ascendancy: from the Arab conquests to the siege of Vienna'' Greenwood Press (2000) p107</ref> who under [[Genghis Khan]] were able to enforce this concept more widely than China. The Japanese attempt to unify South East Asia in the [[Greater East Asia Co-Prosperity Sphere]] under the [[Shōwa emperor]] follows the model set by Imperial Germany and Joseph Chamberlain of imperial rule based on economic union, matched with Japanese religious ideas.
The Hindu/Buddhist concept of the [[Chakravartin]] is a perfect illustration of the ideal of a Universal Monarch.<ref>Bhandarkar, D. R. ''Lectures on the Ancient History of India from 650–325 B.C.'' University of Calcutta (1919) pp85–86</ref><ref>Beér, Robert ''The encyclopedia of Tibetan symbols and motifs'' Serindia Publications 2nd Revised edition(2004) pp160–161</ref>
